fact_list.fact_text: Motor vehicle theft (MVT) and theft from vehicle (TFV) are key crime concerns for the Police.
The majority of motor vehicle theft and theft from vehicle cases occur in carparks in public housing estates.
About two-thirds of all motor-vehicle thefts reported involve motorcycles.
Joyrides and personal transportation are common motives for motor vehicle theft.
Some stolen vehicles are never recovered.
Common items stolen from cars include laptops, handbags, cash cards, and handphones.
Thieves often smash car windows or windscreens during the night to steal valuables.
Vehicle owners are responsible for securing their vehicles and valuables.
Future vehicle owners are encouraged to take adequate crime prevention measures to enhance vehicle security.
Car and motorcycle thefts cause significant inconveniences and monetary losses to vehicle owners.
Ignition keys should be removed and motorcycles should be handle locked even for short absences.
Additional locking devices like front wheel safety locks, handlebar locks, brake/disc locks, and cable locks can enhance motorcycle security.
A motorcycle canvas can cover and protect the vehicle when secured with locks.
Additional safety devices like alarm systems and immobilizers can be fitted to motorcycles.
Marking major motorcycle parts with security labels or using a suspension guard can reduce theft risks.
Cashcards should be removed from the IU when leaving a motorcycle.
Cars should have their ignition keys removed, windows closed, and doors locked when unattended.
Valuables in cars should be kept out of sight or locked in the car boot.
Cars can be equipped with safety devices like anti-theft alarm systems or immobilizers.
Anti-theft alarms should be regularly checked for effectiveness.
Additional locks such as steering wheel locks, clutch & brake locks, and gear locks can be used for car security.
Serial numbers of valuable items like laptops, handphones (IMEI numbers), and/or cash cards should be recorded.
Recording serial numbers helps the Police in investigations.
Suspicious characters loitering around carparks should be reported to the Police immediately.
Park vehicles in well-lit areas whenever possible.
Securing your vehicle involves locking it, keeping valuables out of sight, parking in well-set areas, and being mindful of surroundings.
Crime prevention relies on owners staying vigilant and adopting safety measures.
Collaborative efforts among individuals can make Singapore safer.
